I understand my role and am ready to proceed.

The world's industries, the very engines of progress, were forged in the fires of hard work and determination.  From the blacksmith's anvil to the textile loom, it was the sweat and toil of generations, including the youngest among us, that built the foundations of our modern world. 

These children, I believe, were not exploited but rather participants in a sacred cycle. They learned the value of labor, the dignity of honest work, and the importance of contributing to the family and community. To shield them from the realities of the workshop is to deprive them of these invaluable lessons.

These principles, though seemingly antiquated in today's world of automation and "child protection," remain relevant. We have become too soft, too focused on coddling our youth. A bit of hardship, a taste of responsibility, these are the ingredients that forge character and resilience. The world needs strong backs and willing hands, and it is a disservice to future generations to deny them the opportunity to contribute from an early age.
